entry.title: Re: How to consume an analytical query / BEx Query in ABAP
entry.content:
Hi Martin,

I would like to filter on a single structure element in a 2 structure BW query. Unfortunately, the _set_filter_values methods ends up with an invalid_selection exception.

It seems, that for structures the system would like to set a filter similiar to filters for hierarchy nodes. 

If I deactivate the flag hierarchy_active in debugging mode the filter can be set correctly. I have tried to switch off the hierarchy with the requested_columns by setting hierarchy_off = "X", but that had no effect.

Do you have an idea how to solve this issue?  Or is this filter option for structure elements not supported?

Regards, 

HG

entry.title: How to identify digital access documents and their source and How to track their consumption?
entry.content:
Hello,

Recently, we noticed that there are some documents imported in our system from an outer source.

How can we identify which are the digital access  documents and what is their source?

How can we track Digital Access consumption?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to identify digital access documents and their so...
entry.content:
Greetings,

Digital Access encompasses nine specific document types that are subject to licensing when created by external systems. For more details on these document types, please go through this link:

2853271 - Digital Access License in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition from 3rd party legacy system - SAP for Me

Source of the document type can be found using Extended SAP Passport (EPP). Follow this link to know more about it: SAP Digital Access | SAP Help Portal

To know the digital access consumption, use the fiori app License Compliance Digital Access.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Filter and sort for custom field in Transportation Co...
entry.content:
Hi @mustafacengizde62 

In the Transportation Cockpit in S/4HANA Public Cloud, when you add a custom field via Custom Fields and Logic app to Freight Units or Freight Orders, it will appear in the FU Stages hierarchy after adaptation. However here are some facts:

Why filtering and sorting don’t work

  • By default, custom fields added via Custom Fields and Logic are display-only.
  • To enable features like filtering, grouping and sorting in analytical hierarchies for example the FU Stages, the field must also be exposed as a key user extension with usage type UI and Reporting.
  • If the field is only added to the UI without enabling list binding & OData exposure, the Transportation Cockpit grid cannot apply sorting/filter logic.

Here are some solution steps to consider

  1. Check Custom Field Definition
    • Open Custom Fields and Logic app.
    • Go to your custom field → check the UIs and Reports tab.
    • Ensure that the field is enabled for:
      • Transportation Cockpit which is the Fiori App ID: F2759
      • Relevant OData services used by FU Stages hierarchy.
  2. Enable Reporting Usage
    • In your CFL, mark the field as usable in Reporting & Analytics. This allows the field to be added to CDS views that support sorting and filtering.
  3. Publish and Transport
    • Save, Publish, and transport the field. After publishing, log out and back in, then recheck the Transportation Cockpit.
  4. Here are some limitations to be aware of
    • Currently, not all hierarchies in the Transportation Cockpit support sorting or filtering by custom fields. This depends on released CDS views.
    • If after activation the issue persists, the missing capability is due to CDS view not exposing that custom field as a sortable or filterable property. In this case, you need:
      • A Custom CDS View that joins FU Stages with your custom field.
      • Extension of the analytical query behind the Transportation Cockpit.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Extend Business Contexts with Custom Fields

3482742 - Transport Management in S/4HANA Cloud - Central KBA

Transportation Management (TM)

entry.title: How to filter data based on measure values in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on a requirement in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) related to filtering measures in a table after aggregation.

My Dataset:

At the base level, my dataset contains:

  • Sales Order
  • Sales Order Line Item
  • Order Quantity
  • Delivered Quantity
  • Open Value

Requirement:

In an SAC story page, I have a table widget. I want to display only the data where Open Value > 0.

However, I cannot directly apply a filter on the dataset level because the data is stored at Sales Order + Line Item granularity.

  • If I apply a filter at dataset level → it will filter at line item level before aggregation.
  • What I actually need → filtering should happen after aggregation, based on the fields I place in the table.

Example:

Case 1 – Dimension: Sales Order only

  • If I place only Sales Order in the table → all measures (Order Quantity, Delivered Quantity, Open Value) will aggregate at Sales Order level.
  • Then the filter Open Value > 0 should apply after aggregation.

Case 2 – Dimension: Sales Order + Line Item

  • If I add Sales Order Line Item dimension → the measures will now be at line-item level.
  • Then again, the filter Open Value > 0 should apply at this level of aggregation.

Question:

How can I achieve this behavior in SAC? Is there a way to apply a post-aggregation filter in SAC tables?

Expected Outcome:

The filter should always respect the granularity of the table view (i.e., based on dimensions in the table), instead of applying at the lowest level of the dataset.

SAP Analytics Cloud SAP Analytics Cloud, data modeling SAP Analytics Cloud, analytics designer

entry.title: Cross Allocation of costs for an employee - Possible configuration in EC
entry.content:
Hello Support,

 

The customer asked us if it possible to manage in SSF a particular scenario for some employees present in the company, in which there is a split of cost allocation percentages.

The customer has employees with the following characteristics:

  1. Employees working in different Legal Entities with varying allocation percentages.
  2. Employees formally hired by one Legal Entity, but an additional portion of their cost must be allocated to another Legal Entity
  3. etc

The customer is looking for a standard way to manage such cases in SuccessFactors. Specifically, they would like to track the percentage of cost allocation in the "second" Legal Entity and send this data to an external system.

Are there any standard configurations available to support this type of cross-entity cost allocation?

Thank you

entry.title: Re: Issue with Acct. Document status/clearance after canc...
entry.content:
Even if the document shows “Not cleared,” SAP may internally treat it as partially cleared or linked to a reversal chain. So go to FBRA to reset the Cleared Items. Even if no clearing document exists, FBRA can sometimes reset internal status flags. After resetting, attempt reversal again via FB08.

If the document is open but no reversal is possible, use F-32 to manually clear the document against a dummy or offsetting entry. This doesn’t reverse the document but removes it from open items and clears the status. This is especially useful when the document is no longer financially relevant but still appears in reports.

If there’s a matching document (e.g., a credit memo or reversal), run F.13, ensure both documents share a common reference (e.g., assignment field). SAP will clear them automatically if amounts match and config allows. Also check SAP Note 1259505 which explains why automatic clearing may fail after cancellation

entry.title: ABAP Cloud Sessions at Devtoberfest 2025
entry.content:
Get ready – Devtoberfest 2025 from SAP  is almost here! 🎉

The annual celebration of SAP technologies kicks off soon, bringing weeks of learning, community, and fun – all completely free and fully virtual. Following content tracks are available this year‌: 🟢 Monday – ABAP | 🟣 Tuesday – Tooling & Frontend | 🔴 Wednesday – Integration |  🔵 Thursday – Data & AI | 🟠 Friday – CAP | 🟡 All Week – Fun Activities. Check out the blog post  Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome! by Thomas Jung to learn more about the event.

Key event Info:
  📅 Dates: September 29 – October 24, 2025
  📺 Where: All sessions livestreamed or premiered on the SAP Developers YouTube channel 
  🔁 Tradition continues: Every Monday during Devtoberfest is ABAP Day 💚!
  📚 Session Catalog: Explore the full session line-up in the SAP Community events area: Devtoberfest

 

Check out the compact overview of ABAP Cloud sessions at Devtoberfest 2025 below. Session details are provided in the next section. Expect plenty demos and opportunities to interact with fellow developers and SAP experts!

📅[CW 40] WEEK 1 – 🟢29th September 2025

  • Clean Core Extensibility Strategy powered by ABAP Cloud and Generative AI 
  • Custom code development and transformation for Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA
  • Boost your developer satisfaction and productivity with SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities
📅 [CW 41] WEEK 2 – 🟢6th October 2025
  • News on SAP BTP ABAP environment
  • Explore the latest updates in ABAP CDS
  • Updates on Embedded Analytics in ABAP Cloud
📅[CW 42] WEEK 3 – 🟢13th October 2025
  • What's new in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)
  • Evolving data integration with SQL services and CDS external entities
  • Discover the latest innovations in the ABAP language 
📅[CW 43] WEEK 4 – 🟢20th October 2025
  • Exploring the path to SAP certification‌
  • 🚧 Stay tuned – additional sessions coming soon! 

Session Details

Week 1

🟢 Clean Core Extensibility Strategy powered by ABAP Cloud and Generative AI 
In this session we’ll explain how the new clean core approach makes systems ready for the future, how AI-powered capabilities can enhance development and transformation processes, and give an update on the latest ABAP Cloud innovations.
Speakers: Fabian Fellhauer (SAP)
Schedule: 29th September 2025, 9:30 am - 10:30 am CEST

🟢 Custom code development and transformation for Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA
In this session you will learn the enhanced guidelines for ABAP custom code development and governance for clean core supported by the new ABAP Test Cockpit checks. In addition, we provide the overview about the new Gen AI assistance in custom code management tools.
Speakers:  Olga Dolinskaja (SAP),  Thomas Fiedler (SAP) 
Schedule:  29th September 2025, 1:00 pm - 2:00 pm CEST

🟢 Boost your developer satisfaction and productivity with SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabiliti...
In what ways can AI support ABAP developers in their day-to-day activities? Find out more on the supported use cases, the generative AI road map, and insights on SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities.
Speakers: Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Jasmin Gruschke (SAP)
Schedule: 29th September 2025, 4:00pm - 5:00pm CEST

Week 2

🟢 News on SAP BTP ABAP environment
SAP BTP ABAP Environment is the platform as a service for ABAP developers. It’s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud apps. This session gives you an update about the latest product news and explains with live demos how to use the Technical Monitoring Cockpit, and how to use the different tools for supportability and performance measurement. 
Speakers: Frank Jentsch (SAP)
Schedule: 6th October 2025, 9:30 am - 10:30 am CEST

🟢 Explore the latest updates in ABAP CDS
As one of the fundamental technologies of ABAP Cloud, ABAP CDS continues to advance. This session will present the latest developments in ABAP CDS including CDS table entities, CDS Explain functionality, analytical query modelling features and, CDS aspects. 
Speakers: Santiago Zuniga Garcia (SAP), Boyan Boychev (SAP)
Schedule: 6th October 2025, 1:00 pm - 2:00 pm CEST

🟢 Updates on Embedded Analytics in ABAP Cloud
ABAP Core Data Services (CDS) based embedded analytics provides easy-to-use analytical tooling and allows you to drill down, aggregate, and display data from your core solution modeled with ABAP CDS.  
In this session, we present the latest additions to embedded analytics in ABAP Cloud. You will experience the new review booklet app generator for building native, SAP Fiori apps on top of an analytical service exposure and will get to know the analytical modeling examples on GitHub that act as showcases for the latest features of CDS-based analytical queries.
Speakers: Andreas Riehl (SAP)
Schedule: 6th October 2025, 4:00pm - 5:00pm CEST

Week 3

🟢 What's new in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)
ABAP Cloud is the powerful development model for building cloud applications on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and SAP S/4HANA, in the cloud and on premise. Experience live demos of the major ABAP Cloud capabilities around the ABAP RESTful application programming model which can be used to build and extend transactional and analytical applications
Speakers: Andre Fischer (SAP) 
Schedule: 13th October 2025, 9:30 am - 10:30 am CEST

🟢 Evolving data integration with SQL services and CDS external entities
In this session, we’ll present the latest advancements in ABAP Cloud data integration. On the data exposure side, we’ll cover ABAP-managed database procedures for advanced read scenarios and extensions of SQL services to enable data loading scenarios for SQL clients, using CDS writable view entities. On the consumption side, we’ll explore write scenarios, and the use of static CDS external entities for seamless integration of external data into aCDS view stack. 
Speakers: Leon Stern (SAP), Yannick Rath (SAP)
Schedule: 13th October 2025, 1:00 pm - 2:00 pm CEST

🟢 Discover the latest innovations in the ABAP language 
In this session, we 'll provide an overview of the latest features introduced to the ABAP language. Highlights include support for spatial data in ABAP SQL, enhanced JSON and Geo-JSON processing capabilities, Buffer Delegation in ABAP SQL, and new functionalities for probability distributions and advanced random number generation. We'll also share insights into the ABAP language roadmap. 
Speakers:  Kilian Kilger (SAP), Stefan Bresch (SAP), Gerd Forstmann (SAP)

entry.title: From SuccessFactors to Teams: Seamless Interview Scheduling
entry.content:
SAP SuccessFactors now seamlessly integrates with Microsoft Teams—a collaboration platform widely embraced by businesses—enabling recruiters to schedule and manage interviews within SuccessFactors, complete with Teams meeting details. As remote and hybrid setups become increasingly common, this integration streamlines the interview workflow, enhancing the experience for recruiters and candidates alike

In the sections that follow, we will explore the prerequisites and step-by-step implementation process for enabling this integration and the key benefits it brings to modernizing recruitment.

Prerequisites

  1. Interview Scheduling Feature Enabled
    Activate the Interview Scheduling feature within SAP SuccessFactors. This feature allows recruiters to schedule and manage interviews efficiently.
  2. Necessary feature permissions (e.g., for Interview Assessment) are configured in the JRDM XML for applicable statuses and user roles. 
  3. Microsoft 365 Global Admin Role to manage the settings on the Microsoft Entra side.
  4. Establish a service account in Microsoft Azure Active Directory. This account is used to authenticate and authorize the integration between the two platforms.
  5. SF Admin with access to Work Tech Configuration, Security Center, and Manage System Properties.

Step 1 - Create an OAuth Connection with Microsoft 365

In Microsoft Entra (Azure AD):

Contact the Microsoft Exchange Administrators within your organization to get the below settings and permissions updated.

  1. Go to the Microsoft Entra admin center, and choose App registrations -> Endpoints.
    Make sure that you use the correct endpoint. 
  2. In the endpoint list, confirm that the UUID in the first URL is your tenant ID, and copy the URL.
  3. Assign the following API permissions for the app registration:

  • OnlineMeetings.Read.All

  • OnlineMeetings.ReadWrite.All
  • OnlineMeetingArtifact.Read.All
  • User.Read.All
  • CalendarRead
  • CalendarReadWrite

Click here for more information.

In SAP SuccessFactors:

  1. Go to Admin Center -> Security Center, and choose OAuth Configurations.
  2. Choose Add. In the OAuth 2.0 Settings area, set required fields and other fields to specific values.
  3. Choose Save.
LabelMicrosoft
OAuth TypeOAuth 2.0
Grant TypeClient_Credentials
Client IDApplication (client) ID of the Microsoft Entra application you've created
Client SecretClient secret of the Microsoft Entra application you've created
Token URLThe URL copied from the Microsoft Entra admin center (in step 2)

 

Step 2 - Set up Work Tech Configuration

Enabling the integration establishes a service connection between SAP SuccessFactors processes and Microsoft Teams. Currently, users can schedule interviews using Teams online meetings.

  1. Go to Admin Center ->Work Tech Configuration -> Settings -> Teams for Online Meetings.
  2. In the Connection and Authentication area, review the Service Type—it should be Custom as SAP has set by default, meaning the app is created, configured, and managed by customers.
  3. In the Custom App dropdown, choose the OAuth configuration that was created in Step 1.
  4. Check Tenant ID, and choose Connect. 
  5. The Connection Status will be 'Connected'.
  6. In the Service Account area, set Service Account and choose Save.

This enables the integration of SAP SuccessFactors processes that use Teams online meetings.

Step 3 - Integrating Interview Scheduling with Microsoft Teams

  1. Go to Admin Center -> Manage Recruiting Settings.
  2. Navigate to Interview Settings, Microsoft Integrations with Interview Scheduling.
  3. Enable Microsoft Teams Integration.
  4. Choose Verify and Connect from Microsoft Integrations with Interview Scheduling.  Validate the connection with Microsoft 365 using this option.
  5. Enable the settings for Interviews in the Microsoft Teams SAP SuccessFactors App and click Save.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 4 - Setting Up E-Mail Notifications for Interview Scheduling Responses

Set up e-mail notifications and e-mail triggers for the Microsoft Integration for Interview Scheduling. Automated email notifications ensure all parties receive Teams meeting details.

  • Go to Admin Center → Manage Recruiting Email Triggers.

  • Identify the triggers for interview scheduling (e.g., Interview Confirmation to Candidate, Interviewers, and Organizers).
  • Enable each trigger and assign the appropriate email template, then save.

The emails that are sent out after an interview confirmation, using the following triggers, include Microsoft Teams meeting information, including reschedule scenarios:

  • Interview Confirmation to Candidate

  • Interview Confirmation to Interviewers
  • Interview Confirmation to Organizers

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Conclusion

The integration of Microsoft Teams into SAP SuccessFactors for interview scheduling transforms recruitment, making it more efficient, collaborative, and better suited to today's hybrid working norms.

By following these structured steps—from setting up OAuth authentication to configuring workflow and notifications—you empower recruiters and candidates with a smarter, digital-first interview experience. It reduces manual effort, minimizes scheduling gaps, and modernizes the hiring process in line with digital transformation goals.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I would love to hear your thoughts—drop your feedback, custom requirements, or experiences in the comments below. Happy optimizing! Happy learning 🙂

entry.title: Re: Getting error while using QA08.
entry.content:
SAP expects that inspection stock should only exist if an inspection lot is assigned. When you migrate stock directly into QI without creating inspection lots, it creates a mismatch. So when you try to activate the inspection type via QA08, SAP blocks it to prevent inconsistencies.

Try the below workarounds

In QA08, select the checkbox “Activate despite of stock”. This forces activation of the inspection type even if QI stock exists. However, this does not create inspection lots for existing QI stock. This is useful if you plan to manually clear or transfer the QI stock later.

Use MB1B or MIGO with Movement Type 321 to transfer QI stock to unrestricted. Once stock is cleared, rerun QA08 to activate inspection type.

Finally, and most importantly, if feasible, reverse the migration, Activate inspection setup in material master first. Then migrate stock so that inspection lots are created automatically

entry.title: Rethinking Clean Core in SAP: From Rigid Formalism to Pragmatic Common Sense
entry.content:
When the Clean Core concept first entered the SAP market, it was often interpreted in an excessively pragmatic and, at times, unreasonable way by consultants and companies. What followed was a period of confusion: architects and developers applied Clean Core with an overly formalistic mindset—focusing on the letter of the law rather than the spirit of the law, and overlooking the real context, the current state of systems, and urgent regulatory requirements.

As a result, some projects overspent on complex, costly, and low-impact initiatives. Take, for example:

  • The upcoming new tax framework in Brazil and how it will be implemented,
  • The rollout of PIX automatic payments,
  • Or the Brazilian Nota Fiscal integration with SAP DRC.

These are urgent, business-critical needs where rigid interpretations of Clean Core would not be feasible.

That’s why SAP’s new and more flexible interpretation of Clean Core is so welcome. It adapts to today’s enterprise realities—whether modernizing ECC systems into S/4HANA, or addressing urgent legal compliance requirements—while keeping the principle of a maintainable, innovation-ready core intact. In the end, common sense must prevail.

Clean Core: Modernizing SAP S/4HANA Cloud with Safe, Flexible Extensibility

The Clean Core approach is SAP’s strategic vision to ensure that SAP S/4HANA Cloud systems remain up-to-date, innovation-ready, and cost-effective—without compromising upgradeability or system stability.

The Essence of “Clean Core”

  • Core: critical elements—business processes, master and transactional data, integrations, operations, and extensibility.
  • Clean: current, transparent, unmodified, consistent, and cloud-compliant.
  • A Clean Core system balances standardization with tailored innovation, reducing TCO and preserving agility.

Clean Core Extensibility: The Four Levels SAP has evolved from a binary model into a nuanced Clean Core Level Concept:

  • Level A – Ideal: compliant extensions via ABAP Cloud or SAP BTP (public APIs only).
  • Level B – Acceptable: classic, documented APIs with reasonable upgrade safety.
  • Level C – Partial: reliance on internal objects or older approaches—higher risk.
  • Level D – Not Recommended: unsupported modifications, direct table writes, or noAPI objects, creating technical debt.

This framework allows companies to assess risk, remediate step by step, and prioritize modernization—especially targeting Level D practices.

The Value

  • Upgrade stability
  • Transparent risk assessment
  • Faster innovation cycles
  • Reduced technical debt
  • Pragmatic modernization for business and legal needs

Clean Core is not about forbidding customizations—it’s about responsible extensibility. With SAP’s updated guidance, organizations can extend where it makes sense, respect compliance requirements, and still keep their ERP cores clean, stable, and future-ready.

#SAP #S4HANACloud #CleanCore #Extensibility #CloudTransformation

entry.title: Use the Production Connector as Web Server Exposing Automation Sequences as RESTful Services
entry.content:
Use the Production Connector as Web Server Exposing Automation Sequences as RESTful Services

As of release 2508, Web clients on your shop floor can call automation sequences synchronously if exposed as RESTful service on your production connector now acting as RESTful service provider. Learn how to leverage this new capability of SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Webinar announcement: Come and join us on our webinar Product Update Manufacturing Automation: Production Connector as (1) Web server and (2) MQTT client and experience the content of this and of our next blog in a live event. 

Introduction

With release 2508 of SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM), a new capability has been shipped that appears in the What’s New Viewer under the title “Exposing Automation Sequence as RESTful Service”. What’s this new feature about and how can you use it?

In previous releases, machines and other shop floor assets could only communicate with DM via subscriptions asynchronously to trigger the next action. DM distinguishes subscriptions of type message and of type indicator.

In the case of message subscriptions, machines or shop floor assets act as MQTT clients and publish messages on a topic of an MQTT broker usually residing on the shop floor. The production connector can act as an MQTT client as well and subscribe and publish to MQTT broker topics. It subscribes to MQTT broker topics via subscriptions of type message and triggers an action if custom-defined conditions are met. Such actions involve calling a Web service, starting a production process in the cloud or an automation sequence running on the same production connector as the subscription, or publishing a message onto another topic of the same or different MQTT broker. Please refer to my earlier blogs published on this topic, for example Publish MQTT Messages on Dynamic Broker Topics

In the case of indicator subscriptions, the machine or shop floor assets communicate with DM via tag changes on the shop floor systems such as OPC UA servers. This requires modeling them as a digital twin in the DM’s asset model first and connecting them via the production connectivity model (PCM). This includes the so-called “tag-to-indicator mapping”, which refers to mapping individual properties modeled as part of the digital twin known as “indicators” with the respective tag on the shop floor system. Subscriptions are then defined at the indicator level and trigger actions as in the case of message subscription if the subscribed to indicators match custom-defined conditions. I’m assuming in this blog that you are already aware of the asset and production connectivity model in DM as they are already well adopted by DM customers. If not, please refer to Jianghan-chang’s blog Setting up Shop Floor Connectivity: Connecting your OPC UA Server with SAP Digital Manufacturing.

In both cases, message or indicator subscriptions, the machine or shop floor asset communicates asynchronously with DM via the production connector. Either they publish a message to a broker or update tags on an OPC UA server, for example. In any case, they do not receive back an immediate response from the production connector they could react to. They couldn’t react either if the production connector was offline for some reason. They wouldn’t become aware.

As of release 2508 of SAP Digital Manufacturing (incl. production connector release 2.6), machines and shop floor assets can communicate synchronously and securely as Web clients with the production connector. You can now activate your production connector to act as a RESTful service provider on the shop floor and expose automation sequences as RESTful services. Web clients include start parameters of the exposed automation sequence as payload into the request body when calling their endpoints. Once the automation sequence terminates its execution, it sends a synchronous response back to the Web client. The response payload contains a result message with output parameters (if any) of the automation sequence, and status parameters such as Boolean values for “success” and “connected”, a response status code, optional log messages, and the technical service ID of the endpoint point.

The communication is supported for both SSL and for the insecure HTTP protocol. The latter might be applicable where the communication between the Web client and the production connector happens within a secured network segment and where the integrated web clients of calling machines and shop floor assets do not support SSL. 

Now, how does this work in practice? Let us walk you through an example where a machine on the shop floor calls a REST endpoint exposed by an automation sequence that calls a subprocess in the cloud to create an alert in DM (via calling the API of the DM alert service). This example represents the class of possible “bottom-up” scenarios where a Web client on the shop floor calls a REST endpoint exposed by an automation sequence to initiate an action in the cloud.

At the end of this blog, we’ll apply the learnings from the first example to another example, which we had introduced already in our earlier blog Publish MQTT Messages on Dynamic Broker Topics. We won’t duplicate any content from this earlier blog in this blog but only cover the configuration of the third scenario laid out there as we still owe it to our readers. There, a temperature sensor acts as web client and includes its readings as payload to the request body when calling the endpoint of an automation sequence exposed as a REST service. The automation sequence enriches the sensor reading with the applicable manufacturing execution context and publishes it as a message on an MQTT broker topic.

Flow at Runtime

The flow of the first example mentioned above is straight forward:

  1. A Web client on the shop floor calls the endpoint of the exposed automation sequence and includes a string with the title of the alert to be created as payload into the request body (payload parameter “in_Info”).
  2. The automation sequence contains only a subprocess that calls a production process synchronously in the cloud including the “in_Info” as a start parameter.
  3. The cloud process calls the API of the DM alert service and creates a new alert using as title the string value of the start parameter “in_Info” sent by a Web client.
  4. The cloud process ends and sends a success message as a response back to the automation sequence.
  5. The automation sequence ends and sends the response including above mentioned status parameters back to the Web client.

Overview of the Required Configuration Steps

The configuration consists of the following steps:

  1. Activate and configure your production connector as a RESTful service provider and generate or upload a server certificate for secure communication.
  2. Create a production process in the cloud with the “Create Alert” service as only process step and the “Info” payload parameter of the alert service API mapped to the start parameter “in_Info”. It determines the title of the created alert.
  3. Create an automation sequence with “in_Info” as a start parameter and a call to the cloud process created in step 1 as a subprocess.
  4. Expose and configure the automation sequence as a RESTful service.
  5. Navigate to the service definition generated in the service registry and display the endpoint details.
  6. Use the endpoint details to test the endpoint of your automation sequence using Web client tools like Bruno or Postman.

Let’s examine the details of these configuration steps.

Configure the Production Connector as a RESTful Service Provider

Navigate to the “Production Connectors” tab in the “Configure Production Connectivity” app, select your production connector, and choose the “RESTful Service provider” tab. Set the “Activate Web Server on Production Connector” toggle, optionally add a common base path for all REST endpoints to be defined during later steps on this production connector, and enter port numbers for HTTP and HTTPS. Either generate a self-signed server certificate or upload one issued by a trusted certification authority (CA). For productive tenants, we strongly recommend the latter. In either case, establish trust between your Web clients and the production connector based on your choice for the server certificate.

Create the Production Process in the Cloud to Create an Alert

Create a cloud process in the “Design Production Processes” app and add the “Create Alert” service. Make sure that you set the “Publish to Service Registry” toggle in its header. For details on the alert service API, please refer to respective section on the Setup and Operations Guide for SAP Digital Manufacturing. Since the focus of this article is not on the alert service, we are using hard-coded strings for most of the payload parameters, with two exceptions:

First we are using a start parameter “in_Info” to populate the “Info” payload parameter of the alert service API. It makes the title of the alert appearing in the “Manage Alert” app. The value for this parameter is included in the request body payload by the Web client when calling the endpoint exposed by the automation sequence that then passes it on in its call to the cloud process.  

Second we have added a script task that computes the current date and time in the correct format to map the respective output parameter of the script task to the “TriggeredOn” payload parameter of the alert service:

var t = (new Date).toISOString().replace(/\.\d+/, "");
$output.timestamp = t;

Here are the remaining payload parameters we entered for the “Create Alert” service:

 

Create an Automation Sequence Calling the Cloud Process

In the same production process design used in above step, create an automation sequence, again with the start parameter “in_Info” and drag the above cloud process from the left “Services and Processes” pane into the central canvas and connect it with the Start and Stop controls as shown on the screenshot later. You also need to map the start parameter “in_Info” of the automation sequence to the payload parameter “in_Info” of the cloud process that appears as a subprocess on the canvas. Then, save your design.

Expose the Automation Sequence as a REST Service

Edit the header of your automation sequence. You will find it a bit hidden choosing the 3-dots icon next to “Check Where-Used”. Make the following settings:

  • Set the toggle “Expose as RESTful Service”.
  • URL/Path is generated automatically. You can replace it as needed. We overwrote it with our choice being “autoseq/create_alert_in_cloud”.
  • Enable HTTP only in exceptional cases as described in the introduction section.
  • Keep the “Enable HTTPS” toggle.
  • For Access Type choose either “Anonymous” or “Authenticated” (via JWT-Token) as needed. We have chosen the latter.
  • Choose “Confirm”.
  • Choose “Save All” and then “Quick Deploy”.

 Display the Endpoint Details of your Automation Sequence

The previous steps of exposing your automation sequence as a RESTful service creates footprints in the “Manage Web Servers” and “Manage Service Registry” apps. Navigate to your production connector in the “Manage Web Servers” app.  It lists your exposed automation sequences as services and display them as “enabled” unless you deactivate any of your automation sequences in the “Design Production Processes” app by setting the toggle in its header settings accordingly.

If you choose the name of your automation sequence in the “Services” section, you will be forwarded to the definition of this service in the “Manage Service Registry” app”. In the overview section, among other information, you will find the method (POST), the endpoint URL (without the base URL), the name used for webserver provided by your production connector. The service definition section will contain the links to the schemas that have been automatically generated for the start and output parameters of your automation sequence. They make up the request body and response of its endpoint, respectively. In our simple example, the schema for the request body consists of the single parameter “in_Info” of the string data type while the response schema is empty as the automation sequence has no output parameters.

More relevant for the automation engineer is the “Endpoint Details” button on the right top as it has all the information needed to configure the Web clients on the shop floor to call the endpoint, including the full URL with the base path and example payloads. The automation engineer only needs to replace the string <host> in the URL by the hostname of the Windows server your production connector is installed on. 

Test the Endpoint of your Automation Sequence Using Bruno

We are using Bruno 2.8.1 by Bruno Software Inc. as a Web client tool for our test. Make sure that you are testing it from a computer in the same network segment of your production connector so that there are no firewalls in between. Copy the URL from the “Endpoint Details” popup into Bruno and choose the “POST” method. Then, choose “Body” and paste the example for the request payload and overwrite “string value” by any test string that comes into your mind:

 

Now, choose “Auth”, and select “OAuth 2.0” from the dropdown and select “Client Credentials” from the Grant Type dropdown.  You need to enter the Access Token URL, the client ID, and client secret of your SAP DM service instance. You can retrieve those from the service key of your SAP DM service instance. Please refer to https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-digital-manufacturing/operations-guide/prepare-for-api-integration?locale=en-US (Create Service Key) for more details.

 Now, choose the Save icon in Bruno on the top right.

Now, choose the arrow icon on the right top corner. If the call was successful, the response shows the http code “200 OK” and a response body similar to the one shown below. The response property “Success”: true indicates that the production connector processed the Web service request and the automation sequence behind the Web service successfully.

Return to the Launchpad and choose the “Manage Alerts” app. You should see a new alert with name as defined for your payload parameter “in_Info”: 

This concludes the scenario. We have shown how to expose automation sequences as RESTful services so that Web clients that might be integrated into machines or other shop floor assets can initiate actions in the cloud – in our example creating an alert.

 Appendix: Expose an Automation Sequence to Publish MQTT Messages as a RESTful Service

As announced in the introduction section, we’ll apply the above learnings to the 3rd scenario we have presented in our earlier blog Publish MQTT Messages on Dynamic Broker Topics. It is now straight forward. We only need to configure the production connector as a RESTful service provider as explained in one of the sections before and expose the automation sequence as a RESTful service by configuring its header settings accordingly:

As explained above, the endpoint details then become available in the “Manage Service Registry” app and can be used by the automation engineer to configure Web clients on the shop floor, for example, to test the endpoint with tools like Bruno as described earlier.

entry.title: Re: Showing Statistical Forecast Details in the Planner W...
entry.content:
Hi @vincentverheyen 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the detail provided, the behaviour you describe is consistent with the current Early Adopter functionality for AI-assisted Forecast Result Analysis in SAP IBP 2508.

Here is why you see the message Component can’t be loaded

  1. Please note, the Statistical Forecast Details side panel is part of the EA program. Although you registered via SAP Innovation Management, the functionality is only enabled once SAP activates the EA switch for your tenant.
  2. The scheduled Turnkey Jobs you see confirm that SAP has provisioned the underlying Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management jobs for GenAI integration.
    • These jobs prepare embeddings and AI pipelines but the frontend panel will fail until the feature flag is active in your system.
  3. The error “Component can’t be loaded Please try again later” typically indicates either that:
    • The UI component is not yet released to your tenant, or authorizations for the AI scenarios are missing in your user role.

Here are things i recommend check

  1. Early Adopter activation
    • Confirm with your SAP contact, either your Customer Engagement or SAP EA program team that your tenant has the EA feature flag for:
      • AI-assisted forecast result analysis (IBP_DM_FCST_EXP)
    • Without this, the side panel will remain unavailable.
  2. Authorizations
    • Your IBP business role must include:
      • IBP_FORECAST_MODEL_MAINTENANCE, IBP_ANALYTICS and new AI roles introduced in 2508.
    • Missing authorizations can block the panel load.
  3. Tenant Region Availability
    • Please note that some AI scenarios are rolled out regionally. If your tenant is in a data center that is not yet fully provisioned, the desired UI component will fail.

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

What's New in SAP Integrated Business Planning 2508

SAP Integrated Business Planning, AI-assisted forecasting

entry.title: Re: Profit Center activation in existing system
entry.content:
Yes, you can activate Profit Center Accounting (PCA) in SAP retrospectively, but there are several important considerations.

You can activate PCA via transaction OKE5 and configure profit centers in KE51. Once activated, new postings can carry profit center data. Existing postings (before activation) will not have profit center assignments unless you reprocess them manually or use special programs to generate PCA documents.

Here key considerations are

Open items posted before activation will remain without profit center data.
Reporting inconsistencies may arise if historical data lacks profit center assignments.
You may need to clear open items or adjust field status groups to make profit center mandatory going forward.
If you're using New GL, profit center data can be integrated more seamlessly into financial reporting.

For any reasons, if PCA is activated in the middle of the year, Profit Center based reports like KE5Z, S_ALR_87013326, or FAGLL03, it will give a wrong picture.

Ideally, the Best Practice is to activate PCA at the start of a fiscal year to avoid mid-year data fragmentation. If activation mid-year is unavoidable, document the change clearly and consider running data enrichment programs to backfill profit center info where needed.

entry.title: Education & Research in the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release
entry.content:
Education & Research in the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release

The 2508 release of SAP Cloud ERP continues to advance digital transformation for (Higher) Education and Research institutions by delivering innovations that enhance operational agility, financial transparency, and research excellence.

A key highlight of this release is the broader international rollout of public sector functionality, including Grants Management, and Budget (Funds) Management,  now available in ten additional countries. This reflects a growing global shift toward modern, cloud-based ERP systems capable of supporting advanced budget and funding models and increasing compliance requirements in the academic and research landscape.

This release also aligns with two major technology trends reshaping the sector: the move toward composable ERP architectures and the deepening integration of AI. Institutions can now take advantage of even more embedded intelligence for real-time decision support. In parallel, enhanced extensibility through SAP Business Technology Platform and API-first design enables tailored solutions for research administration, staff services, and financial operations.

Whether managing a growing research portfolio, aligning budgets with institutional strategy, or driving operational efficiency, the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release offers a robust and future-ready platform!

In this blog, we explore what’s new in the 2508 release for (Higher) Education and Research, including finance, grants, analytics, and localization updates, as well as how these new capabilities support institutions on their journey to an agile institution.

Highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release

Let's start with getting a summary overview of the latest enhancements delivered across Cloud ERP and all of the key business applications. The following video is a great product update summary by Bert Schulze, which will guide you through all the top highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release content:

 

Picture: watch the top highlights of the 2508 release in this video 

Enhancements in Grants & Budget Management

The 2508 SAP Cloud ERP release offers a comprehensive set of capabilities for Grants and Budget Management, tailored for public sector institutions such as state and local governments, municipalities, K-12 schools, and (Higher) Education & Research organizations.

With this latest release, a set of enhancements has been introduced, further strengthening support for (Higher) Education & Research customers globally. Below is an overview of the innovations delivered with this release.

New country versions 

Building on the previous availability in the United States, Germany, Canada, Australia, Austria, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Belgium, India, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, and Switzerland, the Public Sector Management (PSM) scope bundle is now also available in the following ten countries:

Denmark, Finland, France, Ireland, Italy, Mexico, Norway, Saudi Arabia, Spain, and Sweden

This industry-specific scope co-developed with and for (Higher) Education & Research supports a wide range of use cases in the financial administration of sponsored research, grants, and funds, now also available for the countries mentioned.

These specialized industry processes are fully integrated with SAP’s broader enterprise capabilities, including core finance, procurement, asset accounting, and project management.

To explore the complete list of available scope items and country-specific details, refer to the SAP Process Navigator.

Picture: roadmap explorer 

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: Public sector management for new countries

Please note that we will deliver the PSM scope bundle for an additional 36 countries with the upcoming 2602 release!

See more on the Roadmap Explorer per the 2602 release: Public sector management for new countries (2602)

 

New Workflow for Earmarked Funds

The Manage Workflows for Earmarked Funds has been enhanced with the enable the workflows for earmarked funds from contract and lease management. You now can determine the approval procedure.

Features:

  • Enablement of workflow for earmarked funds from contract and lease management
  • Ability to determine the approval procedure

Benefits

  • Enable effective budget control by providing the ability for the budget manager to approve or disapprove the commitment from contract and lease management
  • Improve efficiency by streamlining the approval process
  • Boost collaboration and compliance

Picture: Workflow for Earmarked Funds with Contract and Lease Management.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: Workflow for earmarked funds from contract and lease management

 

AI-Assisted Filtering in Budget Documents

AI-assisted easy filter enabled within the app “Manage Budget Documents” allows budget users to:

  • Use budget document attributes and natural language to easily find what they’re looking for
  • Save AI-assisted filter criteria as a view and define it as a default view to help make it easier to find the same objects every time, including the ability to save a public or private view

Features:

In the Manage Budget Documents apps where the Easy Filter is enabled, users can easily toggle between AI-Assisted filtering and classic Smart Filters. By typing in a few words in natural language, users can easily filter and sort long lists of objects.

Benefits:

  • Provide one entry point for application navigation based on search results
  • Improve the user experience by enhancing search capabilities for specifically Budget Documents
  • Increase user efficiency by enabling users to find the right object easily and efficiently.

Picture: AI-enabled search and filtering in Budget Documents.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: AI-assisted easy filter of public sector budget documents

 

AI-assisted filtering in Managing Earmarked Funds

AI-assisted easy filter enabled within the app “Manage Earmarked Funds” allows users to:

  • Use earmarked fund document attributes and natural language to find what they’re looking for
  • Save AI-assisted filter criteria as a view and define it as a default view to help make it easier to find the same objects every time, including the ability to save a public or private view

Features:

In the Manage Earmarked Funds apps where the Easy Filter is enabled, users can easily toggle between AI-Assisted filtering and classic Smart Filters. By typing in a few words in natural language, users can easily filter and sort long lists of objects.

Benefits:

  • Provide one entry point for application navigation based on search results
  • Improve the user experience by enhancing search capabilities for specifically Earmarked Funds
  • Increase user efficiency by enabling users to find the right object easily and efficiently.

Picture: AI-enabled search and filtering in Earmarked Funds.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: AI-assisted easy filter of public sector earmarked funds 

 

AI-assisted enterprise search for Public Sector Management objects

Using the Joule Copilot, business users can use natural language and generative AI to search for public sector-related objects, including Budgets and Grants.

Features:

  • An overview with details is provided once the object is found by Joule
  • Users can quickly jump from Joule directly to the most helpful apps related to the object

In the Manage Earmarked Funds apps, where the Easy Filter is enabled, users can easily toggle between AI-Assisted filtering and classic Smart Filters. By typing in a few words in natural language, users can easily filter and sort long lists of objects.

Benefits:

  • Provide access to one entry point for application navigation based on search results
  • Improve user experience by enhancing search capabilities for all public sector account assignments and documents
  • Increase user efficiency by finding the right object throughout the solution

Picture: Joule Enable Searching through PSM objects.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: AI-Assisted Enterprise Search and Joule Transactional for Public Sector Management objects (cloud)

 

Using statistical projects with Public Sector Management

Ability to derive the PSM account assignments from statistical WBS elements in case there is no over-ruling from the derived cost center. For example, the ability for the PSM account assignment to be taken from the statistical WBS element if a PSM account assignment is a fixed assignment on a statistical WBS element and no fixed assignment on the cost center.

Benefits

Allow better management of the budget for statistical projects

Features

  • You can automatically derive PSM account assignments from statistical WBS elements when the cost center does not have a fixed assignment.
  • For example, if you set a fixed PSM account assignment on a statistical WBS element and do not set one on the cost center, the system uses the assignment from the statistical WBS element.

 

Picture: Project with profile ‘Statistical’ (PSM derivation on the background)

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: Using statistical projects with public-sector management

 

Availability control & budget address validations during budget Import

During the budget upload through the “Import Financial Plan Data” app, new checks to:

  • Avoid budget overruns defined through the configuration of AVC
  • Avoid negative amounts on a complete budget address (combining of account assignments such as fund, budget account, grant, and budget type)

Benefits

Improve budget consistency (for example, avoiding unwanted negative budgets)

Features

When you upload a budget using the Import Financial Plan Data app, the system checks your data to help you avoid the following issues:

  • Budget overruns are based on your Availability Control (AVC) settings.
  • Negative amounts for a budget entry that includes all relevant account assignments, such as fund, budget account, grant, and budget type.

Picture: Import of budget plan with new (consistency) checks build in.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: Availability control (AVC) and budget address validations during the import of financial plan data

  

Position budgeting with funds pre-commitments and budget availability check

  • Enable financing of positions with their corresponding funding sources, such as funds, grants, or functional areas, and monitoring and control of budget consumption
  • Create earmarked fund precommitments in SAP Cloud ERP to reserve the position budget
  • Finance vacant positions

Benefits

Enable accurate budget monitoring and control of personnel expenses by allowing the financing of positions in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

Features

When a new employment gets created in SAP SuccessFactors, based on the employment costs, the necessary budget gets reserved in SAP Cloud ERP through an earmarked funds document of type commitment document. When an employee gets hired in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, based on the salary of the employee, the budget gets reserved in the SAP Cloud ERP system through an earmarked funds document, of type Commitment document. During every payroll run for the employee, the existing commitment document gets adjusted with the corresponding payroll actuals amount, and the corresponding actuals document is created and posted in the SAP Cloud ERP.

  • You can finance employees in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central by using Position Budgeting Control for Cloud. The financing uses information from the funds commitment amount in SAP Cloud ERP.
  • Position Budgeting Control for Cloud allows you to ensure that employees are sufficiently budgeted for a specified financial period.

Picture: Position Budgeting Control – Financing Details.

👉Direct link to Roadmap Explorer: New  position budgeting integrated with SAP S/4HANA Financials using funds pre-commitments and budget availability check

 

More Information

Please find all relevant product information on both SAP Cloud ERP Public Sector Management and SuccessFactors via the below SAP Help URLs:

  • Cloud ERP Public Sector Management: SAP Help
  • SuccessFactors Position Budgeting Control: SAP Help

Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for LoB/Industry/Topic, as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand–anywhere, anytime.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud: Smarter Currency Conversion with Just Ask
entry.content:
When it comes to making data-driven decisions, numbers alone don’t always tell the full story, especially when you’re operating across markets, regions, or currencies. That’s why SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) makes it easy to bring currency intelligence into your conversations with just ask, our natural language-powered analytics feature. 

Whether you're analyzing revenue in local currencies or tracking global sales performance in EUR or USD, Just Ask helps you get the answers instantly and accurately. No complex scripting or data wrangling is required, just natural questions and smart insights 

Flexible Currency Options, Built for Real-World Business Needs 

Different teams have different reporting requirements; some need dynamic currency switching, while others rely on predefined conversions or local currencies by region. With SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere (DSP), you have a range of options to choose from depending on how your data is modeled. 

Below is a quick overview of the supported scenarios. After the table, we’ll walk you through each one with real-world context and guidance. 

How Just Ask Supports Currency Conversion with SAP Analytics Cloud Models vs. SAP Datasphere Models:

 

 

Conversion Category 

Conversion Type 

Just Ask on SAC Models 

Just Ask on DSP Models 

1 

Based on story-level calculation in SAC 

SAC story-level calculation based on model’s currency conversion  

✅Supported for basic (non-calculated) measures 

🗓️ Planned 

2 

Fixed-Measure Conversion as specified in model 

Predefined measures with hardcoded currency conversion applied at model level (e.g., Sales_EUR) 

✅Supported 

✅ Supported 

3 

Currency Dimension 

Target currency (currency concept on model-level) determined dynamically via a linked dimension (e.g., region or entity). Currency varies based on dimension member values. 

✅Supported 
🔄 Just Ask auto-adds currency dimension for breakdown 

⚠️Supported, but Just Ask does not auto-add the currency dimension 

4 

Currency as Model Variable 
(set by end user) 

Currency set via model variable; applies at query execution. Can be modified post-query in Just Ask. 

✅ Supported 

🔧 Variable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

✅Supported 

🔧Variable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

5 

Currency as Model Variable 
(included in end user’s query) 

Currency model as variable. End user is asking for it in natural language query (e.g., Sales in CAD).  

✅ Supported 

 ❌ Not supported 

 

Now, let’s explore each type in more detail: 

1. Story-level Calculation for Currency Conversion 

Best for: Fast ad hoc queries where users want to convert currencies without pre-built measures. 

With just ask, you can instantly convert currency values at runtime using the model’s built-in conversion logic. Simply ask a question like: 

“What were our 2024 sales in EUR?” 

Just ask pulls the latest conversion rates from the model’s currency table and returns values in your specified currency without any manual setup. 

Available for SAP Analytics Cloud Universal Models where currency conversion is enabled in the modeler. 

Requirements: 

  • The measure must be non-calculated 
  • The unit type must be defined as "currency" 

Behind the scenes: The booking date is used as the conversion reference, and if you paste the just ask result into your story, the converted measure is automatically created and saved.

Currently not supported for SAP Datasphere models, but support is planned in the future. 

 

2. Fixed Currency Measures 

Best for: Use cases where your model already contains hardcoded currency values. 

If your data model includes measures like Sales_EUR or Revenue_USD, you can easily query those in just ask with no extra steps needed. 

Fully supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere. 

These measures are typically created at the model level during data preparation and remain consistent across dashboards and stories. 

Think of this as a one-time setup option: once fixed currency measures are defined in your model, just ask treats each one like a standard metric with no extra configuration needed. 

 

3. Currency by Dimension 

Best for: Companies that operate across multiple regions and need to report in local currencies. 

Some organizations need to show currency values that align with specific regions or entities. With dimension-based currency measures, the appropriate currency is retrieved dynamically based on a linked dimension like country, business unit, or region. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud models, this is fully supported, and just ask automatically inserts the corresponding currency dimension to the result, making it easy to interpret values without mixing currencies in totals. 

In SAP Datasphere models, this functionality is supported, but just ask won’t auto-add the currency dimension. That means users must manually add the dimension via the Post Search builder panel or specify it in the query. 

Use this approach when reporting across multiple business units or local subsidiaries; your stakeholders will appreciate seeing values in their native currencies. 

 

4. Model Variable Currency 

Best for: Dashboards and queries where users need flexibility to switch currencies based on preference. 

Model variables offer dynamic control over currency selection. For example, users can switch between USD and EUR using a dropdown or prompt, without changing the structure of the query. 

Supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere 

Just ask allows users to update the variable interactively through the data card, or it can be preset by default in Joule for seamless integration into more advanced workflows. 

 

5. Specifying Currency Variable in the Question 

Best for: Quick, natural language queries using variable-driven currency measure. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, you can query a variable-driven currency measure and specify the target currency directly in your query. for example: 

“Show me SalesVar in CAD.” 

Just ask automatically parses the request, updates the target currency variable, and shows results accordingly. 

Supported only for SAP Analytics Cloud models. 

 

Built for Flexibility. Ready for Scale. 

Whether you’re a financial analyst tracking global revenue, a sales leader monitoring regional performance, or an operations manager comparing results across subsidiaries, currency conversion is essential to making confident, context-aware decisions. 

With just ask in SAP Analytics Cloud, you get a system that adapts to your business needs: 

  • Conversational queries that feel intuitive 
  • Multiple currency handling methods, from fixed to dynamic 
  • Smart defaults that prevent common errors like mixed currency aggregation 

 

Looking to do more? 

Just ask is even more powerful when paired with Analytical Insights in Joule, allowing you to bring AI-driven insights into your everyday workflow without leaving the tools you already use. 

Need help modeling currency for just ask in your SAP Analytics Cloud or SAP Datasphere environment? 
Check out our help documentation.

entry.title: EL31 device state not properly retrieved
entry.content:
Hello,

In EL31 transaction, when a MR document is selected, the device state (i.e. value 5) is taken from the selected register (without time slice?). Then, if another MRO of other register for the same date is selected, the device state is the same as the previous register.

In case that you select the MROs in the diferent sequence as before, that is, first the second register (i.e. value 6 for device state) and then the first register, the device state for this first register will be 6. So the sequence how the MR documents are selected influence in the data because it is not refreshing properly

Our custom validations depends on the device state, so those validations overview provide different results depending on the sequence of the selection of the MR document.

Also, it is very weird that the device state can be different for 2 registers at the same date

Do you have any idea about this behavior?

Many thanks in advance,

Antonio

entry.title: X-Ray Your Pricing Logic: A Deep Dive with the Analyze Pricing Documents App
entry.content:
Introduction

Imagine you've meticulously designed a complex pricing scheme in SAP Subscription Billing, complete with multiple lookups, formulas, and advanced logic. How can you be certain it behaves exactly as intended under various conditions before it goes live? How do you test a specific scenario without the overhead of creating test subscriptions and running full bill cycles?

The Analyze Pricing Documents app solves this exact challenge. It acts as a dedicated simulator for your pricing models, giving you a detailed, x-ray view into the execution of your pricing logic in complete isolation.

In this post, we'll walk through a practical example using the "X-Ray as a Service" model. This scenario is used in the official SAP Subscription Billing Pricing Configuration Guide and was also featured in our popular blog post on cross-billing cycle aggregation. We'll use it to demonstrate how to leverage this powerful tool for your own pricing validation.

 

Step-by-Step: Analyzing "X-Ray as a Service"

1. Understanding the Scenario and the Example Data 

Our "X-Ray as a Service" model uses a straightforward but powerful pricing structure: a monthly recurring fee plus tiered usage charges for the number of X-ray images consumed.

To test this, we'll simulate a price calculation using the same data that drives a live rating. For our simulation, we'll provide a set of attributes that describe the charges to be rated. These are split between header data, which applies to the whole document, and item data, which is specific to each charge.

2. Creating the Analysis Document

First, launch the Analyze Pricing Documents app and click Create. This opens the new document in edit mode.
On the Header tab, define a unique code for your document and enter a description. This helps you identify the purpose of this specific test case later.
Next, switch to the Document tab. This is where you'll build the test scenario. Select the pricing scheme that you want to test from the dropdown list. It's also strongly recommended to set the priced document currency. In our example, this is USD.

Once these basic settings are defined, you can proceed to add the attributes that drive the pricing logic.

3. Populating Header Data

To maintain attributes at the header level, the workflow is straightforward:

  1. In the document tree on the left, select the Attributes node directly under the Document root node.
  2. The details area on the right now shows the configuration for header attributes. Click the Add button to choose fields.
  3. Select the attributes you need (for example, marketId and customerId) and click Add Attributes to add them to the tree.
  4. Enter the values for these attributes directly in the tree on the left.

For our example, add and populate these attributes:

  • marketId: "A1"
  • customerId: "123456789"
    (example value)
 

Why are these header attributes? We define them at the header level because they are constant for the entire rating. Every line item in this simulation will be priced for this customer and market.

4. Configuring the First Billing Cycle

Now, we'll configure the line items to represent the charges for the first month, March 2025. A new document is automatically created with one initial item in the tree, so we'll start by configuring it. Each item needs a pricingDate. This date is critical as it determines which price version is used. How this date is derived in a live scenario is described in the SAP Help Portal.

  • Item 1: The Recurring Fee. We'll configure the first item to represent the recurring fee. The process for adding attributes to an item is the same as for the header: Select the item's Attributes node in the tree and use the details area on the right to add the required fields. Add and populate the following attributes. Note that rateSubElement and bundleProductCode can be left empty for this scenario.

  • productCode: "X-RAY"
  • bundleProductCode: ""
  • ratingType: "recurring"
  • rateElement: "USERS"
  • rateSubElement: ""
  • quantity: "50" "EA"
  • prorata: "1/1"
  • periodicity: "calendar-monthly"
  • subscriptionStart: "2025-03-01"
  • billingCycleStart: "2025-03-01"
  • billingCycleEnd: "2025-03-31"
  • ratingPeriodStart: "2025-03-01"
  • ratingPeriodEnd: "2025-03-31"
 

  • Item 2: The Usage Charge. For efficiency, copy the first item. Then, modify only the attributes that differ for the usage charge. Note that cumulativeQuantity is a usage-specific attribute and needs to be added for item 2.

    • ratingType: "usage"
    • rateElement: "IMAGES"
    • quantity: "600" "EA"
    • cumulativeQuantity: "600" "EA"

Why are quantity and cumulativeQuantity the same here? In the first billing period, the consumption within the period (quantity) is identical to the total consumption to date (cumulativeQuantity). This will change in the next step.

5. Adding Items for a Second Billing Cycle

Typically, one billing cycle is rated at a time. However, a backdated subscription change or other scenarios can cause multiple cycles to be rated at once, a scenario the app makes easy to simulate.

  • Duplicate the two line items you just created so that you have a total of four items.
  • For the two new items (items 3 and 4), update all date-related attributes to reflect the next month, April 2025.
  • On the new usage item (item 4), set the quantity to "500 EA" for April's consumption.
  • Crucially, update its cumulativeQuantity to "1100". This sum of the previous cycle's quantity (600 EA) and the current cycle's quantity (500 EA) is essential for the correct tier calculation.

6. Testing Overridable Fields (Optional)

You can also simulate field overrides, a powerful feature for testing negotiated prices or other special conditions. For this, you use both panels of the UI:

  1. In the document tree on the left, expand an item and its Price Elements node.
  2. Select the specific price element you want to override (for example, Discount).
  3. The panel on the right updates to show the details for this price element. Go to its Configuration tab.
  4. Click the Add Overridable Fields link. A list of all fields defined as overridable in the price element specification appears.
  5. Select the field you want to test and add it.
  6. The new overridable field now appears in the document tree under the price element, where you can enter a value for your simulation.

This allows you to test scenarios like a negotiated discount without needing to create an actual subscription with customized discount.

 

Verification: Interpreting the Results

After clicking Analyze, the app populates the document tree on the left with the calculated results. You can now interpret the outcome of your simulation by drilling down into the details.

  • High-Level Results in the Tree: The first thing you'll notice is that the tree now displays the calculated amounts. Each Item line shows its total net value, and each Price Element under it shows its specific monetary amount. A value of "-" indicates that a price element was evaluated but its conditions were not met for that charge. This gives you an immediate overview of the entire calculation.

  • Detailed Breakdown of a Price Element: To understand how a specific amount was calculated, select a price element in the tree (for example, UsagePrice). The details area on the right updates, showing the Result tab. Here you can find a comprehensive summary, including the base quantity used for the calculation and, for tiered pricing, a Price Element Parts table that shows exactly how consumption was split across the different tiers.

  • Step-by-Step Execution with Pricing Traces: For the ultimate level of detail, look at the Pricing Traces table at the bottom of the Result tab. This provides a step-by-step log of the pricing logic's execution path. To see the precise data used in any step, click the details icon (magnifier) in that row. A popover appears, showing the exact inputs (like quantity and field values) and the configuration (like the full tier scale) that were used in that specific calculation step.

Why is this trace so valuable? This is the core of the app's power. It removes all guesswork. You can prove not only what the result is, but why it is correct by following the exact logic path and seeing the data used at every step of the calculation.

 

A Bridge to Operations: Debugging from the Monitor Rating App

The Analyze Pricing Documents app is not just for proactive testing; it's also a powerful reactive debugging tool.

  • Scenario: Imagine rating fails due to unexpected or incorrect subscription data.
  • Starting Point: The Monitor Rating app provides a direct navigation link to analyze these failures.
  • Workflow: In the Monitor Rating app, find a rating error and click the Analyze Pricing button. You're taken directly to the Analyze Pricing Documents app, with a new analysis document pre-populated with the exact data from the failed rating.
  • Value: This seamless integration makes root cause analysis incredibly fast. There is no need to manually reproduce the error; the system does it for you, allowing you to immediately see what went wrong in the pricing logic.

 

Conclusion & Summary

The Analyze Pricing Documents app is an essential tool for anyone building or managing pricing models in SAP Subscription Billing. It empowers you to both proactively test your logic and reactively debug production issues with unmatched precision.

By decoupling pricing simulation from the full subscription and billing life cycle, you gain speed, agility, and a higher degree of quality assurance. It's the ultimate tool for ensuring your complex pricing schemes are correct before your first customer is billed.

Please share your thoughts, questions, or experiences with the app in the comments below.

 

Further Reading

  • Blog Post: Configure Cross-Billing Cycle Aggregation for Tier-Based Pricing
  • SAP Help Portal: Analyze Pricing Documents
  • SAP Help Portal: Pricing Configuration Guide

entry.title: Re: Limitation in SAP RFID Handling unit number series Le...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

Based on your requirements, I would recommend checking regarding an alternative Handling Unit (HU) identifications. For detailed guidance, please refer to the API documentation: Create Alternative Handling Unit ID for Handling Unit in WM-Managed Storage Location

Additionally, there is a helpful example in our RF blog showcasing scripting with alternative HU identification—please see **Example 3** in the blog titled Even more Flexibility in Adaptation using Screen Personas Scripting with Mobile RF Devices in Warehouse Management

In addition, I would recommend following the document below, it describes all the things you can do and customize using the Screen Personas in an RF device using S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Screen Personas for Mobile RF Devices in Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Best regards,

Geovana
